reviewText: Whee. Europa 3, like its predecessors and its cousins Hearts of Iron and Victoria (Crusader Kings as well, but that isn't as hard to learn), is an extremely complex game that is notoriously difficult to learn, not helped by crappy tutorials. I had an edge having been playing this series since its first installment, but it still took some time to get used to everything. So right from the start expect a significant time investment on learning how to play the game, and learning to do well at it. War, Diplomacy, Trade, Exploration, and more. It's all here.\n\nBut it is worth it. Oh yes is it worth it. EU3 is a -gigantic- game with near-endless replayability and a player-driven storytelling ability (creating a story from your own experience of playing the game) in the same league as the Civilization and Sims games. You can play as any country in the world, though the game is a bit euro-centric considering the time period it covers (1399-1821) is the period in history when Europe came to dominate most of the rest of the world. There are several ways to run your country from military badass to money grubbing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The way the game is setup there are actually several ways to win wars other than just beating the other guys armies.  For example, navies can be powerful because you can blocade a country and bankrupt them, easily winning a war without firing a single shot which is really interesting. Paradox have a fantastic collection of history based Grand Strategy Games. Think 'RISK' with a little bit of politics, and that's what you're going to get from Europa Universalis III. Those going in expecting amazing graphics and detailed animated battles will be disappointed, as it's simply not _that_ game.

Fights are math/dice roll based, which take into account unit type, general, terrain, etc so there is depth in the battles. However, visually they are represented by single unit graphic, numbers, and literally dice rolls. I don't mind this, as it suits the desk top game nature that I've come to admire from the Paradox Clausewitz Engine.
Once you overcome this the games become incredibly indepth, with various scenerios based on history appearing throughout the game. You can either follow them as we know them, or change the course of history.

To give you an idea of the scale the game can potentially last over the course of 400 years (if you have all the expansions) from 1399-1821. So you can start at the end of the 'Hundred Year War' and finish around the time of 'Napoleon' with all the history in between.
The latest DLC 'Divine Wind' adds the Far East to EUIII (Japan & China). I haven't had a chance to fully test out this area of the game yet, but it sounds detailed and exciting.

If you enjoy Empire Building (and a slight Dynasty building element), and don't mind a lack of detailed animations to keep your attention span, then this game might be for you.

There's a good thread on GAF, which has plenty of helpful people to help you understand what's going on - http://www.neogaf.com/forum/showthread.php?t=466864

My first experience with Paradox was EU Rome... and any of you who've played it have a good idea why I was wary to pick up another product by the same group.  I heard good things about the mainline series, however, so I waited for a sale on the Complete vesion before purchasing it.  Frankly, I didn't need to wait.  This game is exactly how I like my games.  Polished (which I imagine it wasn't before the various expansions), complex but not terribly challenging unless you make it so.
My one complaint is how this game treats the 'superiority' of the west as fact, rather than a set of very, very lucky coincidences.    For examle, in Japan, when the portugese arrived with arqubusses and some other interesting techniques, the warring daimyos were not late in adapting western techniques to their warfare, soon producing weapons of (debatably) superior quality to the portugese, while feilding armies considerably larger than anything Europe would produce for at least another century.  Why hadn't they already developed those weapons?  Because the sea protected them.  That simple.  Yet, if, in game, trade starts early, shouldn't Japan recieve some boost to tech, and not remail a century behind?   What about the  First Nations of the Americas?  Certainly the horse cultures of the plains couldn't exist before first sustained contact and horse importation, but they developed fast enough after that.  yet, they don't even appear!  Not even on the historical timelines.
Now, my opinon is that this is a very good game that makes some poor historical assumptions.  Still leaves it a very good game, even if that limits it somewhat.  Trade is king, until late game, colonization is overpowered for western factions, and there are definitely ways to game the engine (royal marriages, anyone?).  It is, essensially, a sandbox, and you can choose your own goals, which means creating a great empire isn't required.
All in all?  9/10
Assuming one can deal with/google crawl enough to fix the bugs, it's good.

Firstly let me say, if you don't like strategy games and you don't feel like spending a bit of time feeling like a lost puppy whilst attempting to learn one, this game is NOT for you.  Go play Pac Man or Streetfighter or some other button masher, because this game will just hurt your wittle feelings.
It's old.  The graphics are mediocre at best and god help whatever tonedeaf goober composed the soundtrack.  None of which takes one iota of shine off the proverbial apple that is this game.  Simply put it is a masterpiece of strategic gaming.  To date this is Paradox's definitive opus.  It somehow manages to maintain beguiling simplicity side-by-side with byzantine depth.
When you first start playing around with it you will probably fumble around like a weetodd on a trampoline(no offence to all you 'todds out there), but you'll STILL be able to make satisfying headway.  And once you have a firm grasp of the mechanics you'll be orchestrating Machiavellian plots that will bring massive swathes of the world under your evil (let's just face it you warmongering bastage) grasp.
If you can master the mechanics of this baby you're well on your way to being a fully qualified field marshall of strategic gaming.  I highly recommend this game to anyone just getting into Paradox's line of strategy games.  It's a far more refined product than it's successor game EU 4 is at this point.
10 out of 10 and you can take that to the bank.

reviewText:
The monolithic historical simulator from Paradox gets a makeover with lessons learned from Victoria, Crusader Kings and Hearts of Iron. The most noticeable improvement from EU2 is the 3D graphics and polished interface. The graphics don’t do as much for the look of the game as much as it simplifies the look of the map. Gone is that “boardgame” feel of EU2 as land, cities and armies have more of an organic feel to them rather then just being markers.

A great new improvement is national ideas. By specializing your country in certain aspects of warfare, trade, exploration and colonization or religion, you can get your goals accomplished easier. What is interesting is you will see some nations choose some very ahistorical ideas. In other words, imagine Poland recruiting conquistadors to colonize Central America. (Would they even be called “conquistadors?”)

The AI in EU3 is considerably harder and smarter. If you post an army at a neighbor’s border, don’t be surprised if he does the same. Beyond warfare, allies will betray you, rivals will rush to colonize the best provinces, and nations will band together to stop your expansion.

Overall, EU3 just plays differently than its predecessor. Random events aren’t as “random” as before and every choice you make effects the decisions you will make in the future. This makes the game play along more natural storylines.

The retail version comes with a beautiful 145 page manual that describes pretty much all you need to know to play a game. The tutorials will help you navigate the interface but the majority of learning comes from playing the game itself.

reviewText:
Being from 2007, this game looks TERRIBLE. There are crashing issues as well.

Also, this game is not great. Lots of clicking to get simple things done or to get information that should be readily apparent.

Recruiting units is a pain: Click province, click unit button, click unit. Click next province, click unit button, click unit. Click next province, click unit button, click unit... on and on ad nauseum.

You have to click on individual armies and open up a dialogue to see how large they are. There is no indication for this on the campaign map. Good luck keeping everything straight.

Oh, and good luck selecting a fleet, instead of the port it's next to; or not pulling your hair out trying to get just the ships you want out of a group of fleets (group select, and then individually close each individual fleet you don't want... instead of being able to simply select the one you do want).

Oh, and nations are not labelled on the political mapmode... what's with that? They're color coded, but if you want to see who that is, you have to click on one of their provinces and hope you didn't actually select one of their neighbors who's a slightly different shade of yellow. Again, good luck keeping anything straight.

Trade and diplomacy are similarly inscrutable. They have mapmodes, but centers of trade are not labelled, and there's no visual indication of how trade flows from one place to another; unless you open individial trade center menus and learn to read them. Not for the faint of heart or the casual player.

Basically... skip this one. The only reason I played it at all is that EUIV has trouble running on my machine and I can't afford an upgrade just yet. But even if this were the newest outing... there are a lot of gaps where any game dev who was giving it serious thought might easily have tripped over a better solution than what they have implemented.

I like the historical period and the variety to strategic aspects to develop and succeed with. I have played it and cruised the wiki enthusiastically for dozens of hours and I still learn how to play better every time I play it. The official forum impresses me with its intelligence and historical passion, which also makes me feel good about playing this and Paradox's other games.

To my own taste, being able to play and thrive with a strategy focused on trade, diplomacy, and internal developments is a major plus. Though admittedly as I have got better and better at this I have begun to find peace and stability rather boring and seek out international shenanigans. Especially after I have developed my own little cultural sphere to be 30 years more advanced, laughably more wealthy, at least as fully armed, as any other country, I now like to field my spies and huge surpluses of gold manipulating the finances and political standing of AI countries to affect the balance of power in various regions. This often doesn't work because the AI doesn't use rebel uprisings and my gold reliably, but it's kind of an odd little betting game.

One of my favorite and still ongoing games, I began as the Mamluks and built up as above, but as I began bothering about trying from behind the scenes to support strategic, small European powers to the disadvantage of the larger ones.

Having tried out several mods, I decidedly recommend MiscMods Expanded as a relatively straightforward but impactful set of changes. It's also pretty easy to mod little tweaks into the game yourself with Notepad. Also, if you get tired of the game's being heavily structured toward European domination every time, I've found that changing the prerequisites on Quest for the New World (allows exploration) on a per-tech-group basis to be by far the most expedient element among my measures to spice up the Earth's destiny via their containment.

If you're not looking for a biased opinion on this game; Don't look here. I absolutely ADORE this game. I honestly can't get enough of it. Though it has a massive learning curve after you get the basics of economy, stability, and diplomacy you'll find that this is one of the best of it's kind.
Set in a time period between 1399 and 1821 you begin the game as one of the nations that once (or still does) own any ammount of land throughout the world. From there you manage relations, economy, military, technology, and many other things as you attempt to create a large and glorious nation for your people. Build alliances with your neighbors or lay seige to their lands but beware the Golden Horde of Eastern Europe, or the mighty power of Ming for they have a vast empire and are not to be trifled with. So, mighty King what have you to say for your nation? Are you the mighty who strike with an iron fist, or those who would like to buy out the world? Can you lead your people to greatness, or will you lead them to an early grave?

Gameplay wise the game is fairly simple. Through many menus you'll be able to manage your money, how much you invest in your military and technology, and what policies your nation will take. As for the battles in the game it's all based on the terrain your armies fight in, if you've given your army a general and what general is more effective, and army composition. EU3 doesn't try to win you over with the fanciest graphics, but offers very deep gameplay instead.

That doesn't mean it's ugly or too 'hardcore' for people who are not veterans of the genre. Don´t be put off by reviews warning you about how difficult everything is! Truly mastering the game will take a long time, but it's easy enough to get the hang of things within a few hours. After that, you'll be leading a country through the centuries, using policy sliders and national ideas to guide it into a certain direction. It´s worth it. And whether your country becomes a champion of free trade, a despotic heathen smashing republic or still something else is up to you.

EU3 doesn't have Civ's relentless focus on linear advancement, however. Not every change is necessarily always a good one. Your great and enlightened ideas help your country progress, but they may also ignite revolts and other misery, setting you back years and inviting hungry neighbors in.

If that appeals to you, try EU3 Chronicles (which has all the expansions). I should add that EU4 is out now, but EU3 is still very worth considering, as it looks good, still offers deep and diverse gameplay and runs well on older systems.

Balancing everything in your nation from political to economic to simply trying to figure out why that one pesky province keeps rioting against your (fair) rule is a full-time task, and while you may be forgiven for setting the clock speed to very fast to see that one project to completion, your neighbours may use that precise moment to invade your nation.
